RT @RepMcGovern: As unemployment surges, so will the number of families struggling w/ hunger & food insecurity.

Proud to lead this letter…

If you are enrolled in the Public Service Loan Forgiveness program or Income-Driven Repayment program, these months of paused payments will count towards loan forgiveness. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to call my New Haven District Office at 203-562-3718.
We have also stopped any involuntary collections, so your wages will not be garnished due to the paused student loan payments.

To help student borrowers, Congress’s third coronavirus response package pauses monthly loan payments on Department of Education owned-loans through September 30th. And until that date, interest will not accrue on your loans.

Over the last few weeks, I have heard from thousands of people in Connecticut who are struggling to make ends meet—including those who have lost their job or had to leave their college or university early due to the coronavirus. https://t.co/FjXueDQzAq

Today at 12 PM EST I will be holding a live telephone town hall meeting to provide a federal update on the coronavirus. To participate, dial 855-920-0553 or live stream the event on my website at https://t.co/lg3pkF0ySO. I look forward to hearing from you.

TOMORROW: Join me for a live telephone town hall meeting where I will provide a federal update on the coronavirus. To participate, dial 855-920-0553 at 12 PM or sign up via the link below to be added to the call. I look forward to speaking with you. https://t.co/lg3pkF0ySO

Hundreds of thousands of people have lost their jobs, and many small business owners have had to close shop with no end date in sight. Many do not know how they are going to pay the bills or keep food on the table.

CT has taken strong measures to stop the spread of COVID-19, but small businesses are suffering. To help fill the gap Congress approved $10 billion in disaster relief grants & $349 billion in loans for small & tribal businesses, nonprofits, ind. contractors & the self-employed. https://t.co/kWKJYgM3d8

Today, we finally have a national standard for paid sick days thanks to the Families First Coronavirus Response Act that Congress passed—17 years after I started working on the #HealthyFamiliesAct. Now we need a permanent solution & #PaidLeaveForAll.

These payments are smaller for single filers earning more than $75,000 and married filers earning more than $150,000. You do not have to pay income tax on these payments.
If you have any questions or need assistance, please contact my District Office in New Haven at 203-562-3718.

People are struggling to make ends meet during this time of crisis, and our government needs to step up. #EqualPayDay marks how long a woman must work into 2020 to earn, on average, as much as a man earned in 2019. My House-passed bill, the #PaycheckFairness Act, would ensure women get #EqualPay for equal work.

Women’s work needs to be valued the same as men’s—especially as we deal with COVID-19. Most low-wage workers are women. Their work is essential. They are on the frontline in healthcare, caregiving, food service & grocery stores. They deserve equal pay for equal work. #EqualPayDay https://t.co/AKOGXqUAkO

If you lost your job recently due to the coronavirus, you could eligible for Connecticut unemployment benefits. If you are, you will also receive an additional $600 per week from the federal government through the end of July. To file a claim, visit: https://t.co/X5kpkeLbem https://t.co/XRZcozlhYs

Any one of us can contract the coronavirus, and we must do our best to prevent further illnesses and deaths—especially for vulnerable populations like our seniors and those with underlying health issues.

I urge everyone to follow the CDC’s guidelines and Governor Lamont’s “Stay Safe, Stay Home” policy. Social distancing is not easy, and isolation’s effect on our mental health should not be minimized. But stopping the spread of this deadly disease must be our top priority.
Every minute matters for our healthcare workers, first responders, and everyone at-risk across the country. In our own daily lives, we must continue following the advice of medical professionals.

Congress needs to act urgently to continue addressing the health and economic crisis facing families. We swiftly passed two important coronavirus response bills thus far, but we must do much more to control the spread of this virus.

My thoughts and prayers are with the families of the two individuals in our District who died from complications due to the coronavirus. This pandemic is on our doorstep, and we must do everything we can to stop it. 
https://t.co/XlIkA94TSr

10 years ago, the Obama Administration passed the #AffordableCareAct—legislation that covers over 20 million Americans and protects over 133 million Americans with pre-existing conditions. Today, we continue the fight to #ProtectOurCare and build upon the progress of the #ACA. https://t.co/r5JzRdIMQ1
RT @ctchildrens: We know that parents and families may have many questions regarding the coronavirus. To ensure there is a trusted one-stop…
Work sharing programs were a bright spot in the aftermath of the financial crisis, and we should immediately reinstate federal support for them in the next coronavirus response package.
Moreover, with fewer workers unemployed, there is less of a burden on the Unemployment Insurance benefits system—which is currently being strained in many states.
By expanding federal support for work sharing programs, workers would be able to keep their jobs and companies can avert layoffs and costly rehiring.
Many do not know how they are going to be able to put food on the table and pay their bills. Fortunately, Congress can help make a difference in people’s lives right now.

Businesses are closing and people are losing their jobs right now because of the coronavirus pandemic. Working people and families are facing an unprecedented threat to their economic security. https://t.co/svsCJfMKLo

The absence of direct funding for programs that millions of people rely on is a mistake that must be fixed. As the debate continues over the third coronavirus response package, I will fight to make sure working people and families are put first.
and an expanded and fully refundable Child Tax Credit that applies retroactively can provide the resources people and families need now.

The economic impact families are facing is not their fault, and programs like paid sick days, paid leave, increased food assistance through programs like the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program and the Emergency Food Assistance Program—

Our public health is at grave risk, working families are losing any semblance of economic security, and our most vulnerable are on the precipice. What people in Connecticut and across America need from Congress is an assurance they will be able to weather this storm.
At a time of crisis, we must be concerned for the solvency of major industries that need assistance, but working people, families, and our most vulnerable must be our top priority.
People have lost their jobs, businesses and schools are closed, and families do not know how they are going to be able to put food on the table and pay their bills.

Senate Republicans’ latest bill does not go nearly far enough to help working people and our most vulnerable. 
https://t.co/cnvmt9v1Yt

During this public health emergency, the End Hunger CT SNAP call center will remain in full operation. If you have any questions related to SNAP or SNAP services during COVID-19, please call 866-974-7627. #CTCOVIDRESPONSE @EndHungerCT https://t.co/QZeM3jg7rW

I want to take a moment to express my gratitude to those who have worked to ensure our safety throughout #COVID19. To our healthcare workers, retail employees, cleaning crews, teachers and others—it is because of your work that we will be able to beat this together. Thank you.

Working people need access to paid sick days and paid leave now more than ever. Thank you @AJFaultLines & @melissakchan for shining a spotlight on this issue at this critical time. https://t.co/iy0vs78fdY

If you were not able to not able to join us live, please listen in via the link below to hear our complete discussion. We will weather this storm together. 

https://t.co/okiVsBdMmc

Thank you to all that participated in last night's live Tele-Town Hall discussion on the federal response to the Coronavirus. I was pleased to be joined by Dr. Richard A. Martinello of Yale New Haven Hospital and I hope that we were able to answer many of your questions.

REMINDER: New special enrollment period for health insurance begins today, March 19th. To see if you qualify to sign up for or to modify your health insurance coverage, visit https://t.co/DUWy7iqkfq before April 2nd to #GetCovered. https://t.co/oWOIv2H8KK
This is especially important to protect our seniors and those who have underlying health issues.

Once again, I urge everyone to follow the CDC guidelines if they can: stay home if you are sick, avoid close contact with others and large gatherings, wash your hands frequently, clean frequently touched surfaces, and stock up on essentials like food and prescription medication.

As evidenced by this latest news, every minute matters right now. We need to act boldly and with urgency on behalf of the American people. We all have the power to control the spread of this disease through our daily actions.
Congress needs to address the health and economic crisis facing families during this difficult time. We need to control the spread of this virus and ensure everyone can make ends meet.
This tragic event underscores the need for all of us to do everything we can to protect each other from the spread of this deadly virus.

My heart goes out to the family of the Connecticut man who died today from complications due to the coronavirus, as well as all the health professionals involved who undoubtedly did their best to keep this from happening. https://t.co/98kOUqzo7Q

This is especially important for older adults and people with chronic medical conditions. Together, we will beat this. Thank you.

I urge you and your families to take the precautions outlined by the CDC, like frequently washing your hands, staying home if you are sick, avoiding close contact with others and large gatherings, cleaning frequently touched surfaces, and stocking up on essentials.

That is why Congress has taken swift action on two emergency bills in recent weeks to help our country deal with the coronavirus pandemic and stem its immediate impact on working people, families, and businesses.
This is a time of crisis. With thousands of positive coronavirus cases across the country and the case count rising exponentially, people are rightly concerned. https://t.co/EG3AoBwRe6
Please call our office at (203) 562-3718 or email via our website at https://t.co/EQBpJGkf1t with any questions.
Constituent service representatives will continue to help residents of Connecticut’s Third District with existing and new casework issues involving the federal government.

While staff will no longer be conducting in-person meetings, meetings will still take place over the phone, calls will continue to be answered and messages returned, and constituent correspondence responded to.

As of this week, our New Haven, CT and Washington, DC offices are serving constituents remotely in order to protect the public health and prevent the potential spread of coronavirus. (THREAD) https://t.co/GAQC5PEacF
Joined @WTNH yesterday afternoon to talk about what Congress is doing to deal with the coronavirus on the public health front and help ensure people are economically secure. https://t.co/9tRC14n9Hr
Through this new legislation, we can provide immediate economic security so no one falls through the cracks.

I am disappointed that, in Congress’s latest coronavirus response bill, the administration has left out tens of millions of workers from access to meaningful paid sick days or longer term paid leave, including our frontline health care workers and first responders.

As businesses and schools shut down to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, people are fearful of how they and their families are going to make ends meet. Congress has the power to change that—and we should.

There has never been a more urgent need to expand paid sick days and paid leave to the workers of this country.
https://t.co/oaw2ikiNm9

Excellent interview with @jkbrennan & @ailsachang on how critical it is to follow @CDCgov and medical professionals’ guidance to avoid catching or spreading the coronavirus.  We have a responsibility to protect others and their families. https://t.co/FiykmK4lGf

The hour may be dark, but we can be the light forward. People need a lifeline amidst this pandemic and when they are forced out of work. Let us show them that this community can help, and help them now.
We are also suspending the work requirement for jobless people on food stamps and empowering states to request needed emergency food stamp benefits.

We are also providing $500 million for mothers and their children through WIC, as well as $400 million for food banks through the Emergency Food Assistance Program. This is to help people meet increased demand during this public health emergency.

To protect food security, we provide $250 million for food programs for low-income seniors, particularly those who are home-bound or living with disabilities, including $160 million for home delivered meals.

On sick days and #paidleave, these are temporary measures. While this will help millions, millions are still left out. So, I will build on these programs. It should not, and must not, take a pandemic to get working people the economic relief and stability they need.

To help, we are providing free testing for coronavirus, funding to help stabilize the unemployment insurance system, 14 paid sick days for eligible workers as well as 12 weeks of paid leave for longer term care, and food assistance.
No one should face the impossible choice of their health or their paycheck, but unless we act, countless workers may have to.

This is a time of crisis. Last week we provided $8.3 billion to address the nation’s health needs. Now we are addressing the economic well-being of working people and middle-class families—paid sick days, paid family & medical leave, unemployment insurance & nutrition assistance.

This will be the first time paid sick days and #PaidLeave legislation will be signed into law. I first introduced paid sick days legislation—the Healthy Families Act—in 2004, and paid family and medical leave legislation—the FAMILY Act—in 2013.

https://t.co/7e5Tc4ERK9

I am glad that the USDA granted a waiver for Connecticut to ensure kids whose schools are shutting down will continue to have access to school meals. This is critical for keeping kids in low-income families from going hungry during the coronavirus public health emergency.

Proud to have worked with my colleagues @RepKatiePorter & @RepUnderwood to ensure cost is not a barrier for people getting tested for coronavirus. @CDCDirector Redfield must uphold this commitment. https://t.co/hQpTzmyKeq

This bill is directly targeted at helping working people and families affected by the coronavirus pandemic. Proud that it includes paid sick days, paid leave, food security, and free diagnostic testing for all who need it. https://t.co/3cyAfy9gti

We cannot let officials with conflicts of interest roll back workers rights for corporations. And rules being made by the NLRB deserve public hearings—not to be made behind closed doors. https://t.co/WXGYboJjiw

Instead they are designed – purely and simply – to accelerate a race to the bottom. They can only do further harm to middle class families who are struggling to make ends meet. And after years of flat funding, it is my sincere belief that NLRB needs more resources, not cuts.

Yet, the Trump-controlled NLRB has consistently undermined protections, unions, and workers—taking every opportunity to dismantle workers’ rights to organize. These attacks are not serious attempts to restore jobs or boost economic growth.

The National Labor Relations Board’s role is to ensure that workers can form or join a union, be represented by that union in collective bargaining, and be free from retaliation for doing so. These are basic rights. https://t.co/W6yT35wvQE

We must be able to depend on our public health infrastructure at this critical time, and the CDC is fundamental to that infrastructure. That is why we are not going to cut the CDC’s budget, as President Trump’s budget proposal for next year would do. https://t.co/4mDDU2NQai

The coronavirus outbreak is affecting people in the U.S. and around the world—with the first case just reported in South Africa. We must ensure the CDC can help stop the spread of this virus wherever it is. https://t.co/no4ZaitdUa
We also included funding for gun violence prevention research for the first time in more than two decades—and the CDC is moving forward with hearing from applicants for research grants.
We urgently need to modernize our public health data systems at CDC, which is why I secured $50 million in last year’s funding bill to do just that. https://t.co/KV52TuX8ls
The U.S. remains behind the curve on diagnostic testing, and that needs to change immediately.

Last week, we appropriated $2.2 billion for the CDC to deal with the coronavirus outbreak—much of which will go to state and local health agencies, who are on the frontlines dealing with this crisis. https://t.co/iZSwyi4sHi
The delay in the distribution of testing kits has been unacceptable.

Other countries have been testing thousands of people for weeks. But the U.S. is woefully behind the curve. The low number of positive tests in the U.S. is likely a by-product of under-testing, as opposed to an accurate count of the prevalence of coronavirus in the U.S.

The Coronavirus outbreak is a crisis and there are questions about our country's preparedness and ongoing response efforts. I am very concerned about our nation’s testing capabilities for coronavirus. https://t.co/2JYgUoZ98I
